facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 10, 1961 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Criminal Misc. No. 256-D of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 10, 1961, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Criminal Misc. No. 256-D of 1961., K. Daphtary,

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 14, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. September 14. The Judgment of, the Court was delivered. by WANCHOO, J.--The respondent Jagjit Singh along with two others was prosecuted

facts.text: Respondent Jagjit Singh along with two others prosecuted for conspiracy and under sections 3 and 5 of the Indian Official Secrets Act, 1923.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court order granting bail to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the order of the High Court granting bail to the respondent is erroneous and should be set aside. We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court granting bail to the respondent.

holdings.text: Whenever an application for bail is made to a court, the first question that it has to decide is whether the offence, for which the accused is being prosecuted is bailable or otherwise. If the offence is bailable, bail will be granted under s. 496 of the Code of Criminal Procedure without more ado but if the offence is non bailable, further considerations will arise and the court will decide the question of grant of bail in the light of those further considerations.

anchor.surface_text: Whenever an application for bail is made to a court, the first question that it has to decide is whether the offence, for which the accused is being prosecuted is bailable or otherwise. holdings.text: The error in the order of the High Court is that it did not consider whether the offence for which the respondent was being prosecuted was a bailable one or otherwise.

holdings.text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the order of the High Court granting bail to the respondent is erroneous and should be set aside. We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court granting bail to the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the order of the High Court granting bail to the respondent is erroneous and should be set aside.
